data.title: Robert Lewis Balfour Stevenson (1850-1894)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Robert Stevenson born 1850 Edinburgh, Midlothian, Scotland, United Kingdom died 1894 Vailima, Tuamasaga, Samoa including ancestors + 3 photos + 5 genealogist comments + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

[children unknown]

Profile last modified 4 Jul 2024 | Created 2 May 2012

This page has been accessed 11,511 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Marriage

1.2 Residence

1.3 Death

2 Sources

3 Acknowledgements

Biography

Robert Stevenson was born in Scotland.

Robert Stevenson is Notable.

Robert Lewis Balfour Stevenson was born on 13 Nov 1850 at 8 Howard Place in the New Town, Edinburgh, Midlothian, Scotland. [1][2] He was baptised Robert Lewis Balfour, but from about his eighteenth year dropped the use of the third christian name 'Balfour' and changed the spelling of the second to 'Louis'.[3][4] His family called him Louis. He was the only child and son of Thomas Stevenson and Margaret "Maggie" Balfour.[5]

Robert Louis Stevenson was a prolific writer, most famous for Treasure_Island (1883), The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (1886), Kidnapped (1886), and his children's poem collection A Child's Garden of Verses (1885).[6][7]

He was educated at the Edinburgh Academy (1861-63) and later at Edinburgh University.[8]

Marriage

Robert went to America and married Frances Matilda Van de Grift in May 1880 in San Francisco, California, United States. She had three children from her 1st marriage to Samuel C Osbourne, who she divorced in Jan 1880.

He inherited the tendency towards coughs and fever from his mother and maternal grandfather who both suffered from "weak chests", which later necessitated a desire to reside in warmer climates for his health. He travelled at one time to Australia, and finally settled on the Island of Samoa in Vailima, Tuamasaga.[5]

Residence

1851 Census[9][10]

Census Date: 30 MAR 1851

Place: Edinburgh, Midlothian, Scotland

Address: 8, Howard Place, St Cuthbert's, Edinburgh

Age: 4m

1861 Census[11][12][13]

Census Date: 7 APR 1861

Place: St Andrew, Midlothian, Scotland

Address: Heriot Row, St Stephen, Edinburgh

Age: 10y

1871 Census [14][15][16]

Census Date: 2 APR 1871

Place: Edinburgh, Midlothian, Scotland

Address: 17, Heriot Row, St Stephen, Edinburgh

Age: 20y

Death

Robert Louis Stevenson died suddenly of a stroke, aged 44 years, at his Samoan property on the 3rd of December 1894,[17][18] and as per his wishes, was buried on top of Mount Vaea, overlooking Vailima.[19][20] There is a cenotaph at Saint Giles Cathedral, Edinburgh, City of Edinburgh, Scotland.[21]

His obituary was published 17 Dec 1894 in many publications in England,[22][23] Scotland,[24][25] and the United States. [26][27][28]

↑ Ernest Mehew, "Robert Louis Stevenson", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford: OUP, 2004. Retrieved 29 September 2008 . The spelling "Lewis" is said to have been rejected because his father violently disliked another person of the same name, and the new spelling was not accompanied by a change of pronunciation (Balfour (1901) I, 29 n. 1.

↑ Joseph Chamberlain Furnas, Voyage to Windward : The Life of Robert Louis Stevenson (New York : William Sloane Associates, 1951).
